Comment 2: 
A comment from a python thread: "The thing is that the numerical result of sign() itself
is rarely useful. What you do most of the time is take different code paths based on
whether a variable is positive or negative, and in that case it's more readable to write
the condition explicitly."
(http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1986152/why-python-doesnt-have-a-sign-function)

As to whether it should return an int, consider this Wikipedia
(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quadratic_equation) example for solving quadratic
equations:

x1 = (-b - Sgn(b)*Sqrt(b*b - 4*a*c))/(2*a)
x2 = (2*c)/(-b - Sgn(b)*Sqrt(b*b - 4*a*c))

To avoid conversions and to propagate NaNs, you'd want Sgn to return a float64.
